text: The construction of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has become an exciting and expanding approach to novel materials.

The interest is stimulated not only by the MOFs' fine-tuning structure diversity but also by their extensively potential applications in such areas as separation, molecular recognition, ion exchange, gas sorption and storage, nonlinear optics, magnetics, and catalysis.

Deeply understanding the topology structural aspects of high-dimensional MOFs is one of the most important subjects because it will ultimately accelerate the discovery of new MOF materials for application.
To date, the topologies of many three-dimensional (3D) MOFs generally can be analyzed and categorized with some natural prototypes in metallic or binary inorganic solids.
For example, recently, the corresponding MOFs' replica of α-Po,

have been explored gradually. In these mimic and many other 3D MOFs without mineral prototypes, the connectivity of the building blocks exceeding six remains scarce because of the metal centers' limited coordination numbers and the steric hindrance for ligands.

Nevertheless, such drawbacks can be overcome by using large polynuclear clusters instead of simple metal centers as the nodes because the polynuclear cluster-based nodes generally possess larger sizes, more coordination sites, and smaller steric hindrance for ligands with respect to the simple

Both new 3D MOFs were synthesized using the same reaction mixture of H
O (10.0 mL), but different hydrothermal temperatures were applied:  the non-interpenetrating
was obtained at 160 °C, whereas the 2-fold interpenetrating

was formed at 140 °C, suggesting that the hydrothermal temperatures have critical impact on the construction of 3D MOFs. It is noted that the change of the hydrothermal temperatures to obtain 3D MOFs' interpenetrating and non-interpenetrating structures was rarely performed before, although several MOFs tuned by the hydrothermal temperatures had been documented.

Two novel 3D MOFs containing polynuclear cluster nodes and mixed bridging ligands, [Co
), have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized.
topology structure based on the tetranuclear cobalt(II) cluster node [Co
possesses a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D distorted diamond network structure constructed from not only the binuclear cluster node [Co
but also the mononuclear node Co

. This study demonstrates that using polynuclear transition metal cluster node and mixed bridging ligands can provide 3D MOFs with novel topology structures, and the hydrothermal technique can be utilized to obtain quite different 3D MOFs by controlling the temperatures only.

Chun, Hyungphil; Kim, Dongwoo; Dybtsev, Danil N.; Kim, Kimoon

A non-interpenetrating 3-dimensional metal-org. framework, [Cd4(TCPM)2(DMF)4]·4DMF·4H2O, synthesized by a solvothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate and the tetracarboxylate ligand tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)methane (TCPM), is the 1st metal-org. analog of fluorite (CaF2).  In the structure of the title compd. an eight-connecting tetranuclear cadmium cluster and a tetracarboxylate ligand play the role of Ca2+ and F- ions, resp., in fluorite.

Cu2[o-Br-C6H3(CO2)2]2(H2O)2·(DMF)8(H2O)2: A Framework Deliberately Designed To Have the NbO Structure Type
Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The synthesis of an NbO-type metal-org. framework was achieved by design: o-Br-BDC (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) was used to direct the formation of Cu2(CO2)4 paddle wheel units at 90° to each other and thus yield the target network.  The compd. was formulated as Cu2[o-Br-BDC]2(H2O)2·(DMF)8(H2O)2 (MOF-101) and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction [cubic, space group Im‾3m with a 21.607(3) Å, Z = 6], which fully confirmed the presence of the expected structure.  Despite having very large apertures and voids, MOF-101 has a noninterpenetrated structure, an intriguing observation that is discussed in the context of dual structures.  Thermal gravimetric anal. showed loss of all guest mols. at <100°, loss of coordinated water mols. at 100-300° and decompn. of the framework at 300-400°.  Exchange of guest mols. was shown to occur with a variety of solvent mols.

The use of a bulky multifunctional ligand, 9-acridinecarboxylic acid (HL), is key to the successful construction of a neutral 3-dimensional Cu coordination polymer, [{Cu2(μ2-OMe)2(L)(HL)}(H2O)0.69]n, the x-ray crystal structure of which shows 1-dimensional open-channels and the first interpenetrating NbO-type network.  The absorption properties of the complex were studied.  Approx. 6.0, 3.7 and 4.3 mmol N2, EtOH and MeOH, resp., were absorbed per 1.0 g anhyd. sample at a pressure of 0.8 P0.

The title compd., Cu(Pyac)2 (bis[3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dionato]copper(II)), crystallizes from anhyd. solvents in a simple square-grid topol., but when water is present, crystals form with an unusual interpenetrated 3-dimensional NbO topol. whose pores contain hydrogen-bonded solvent mols. Interwoven metal-organic framework on a periodic minimal surface with extra-large pores
Chen, Banglin; Eddaoudi, M.; Hyde, S. T.; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M.
American Association for the Advancement of Science

A strategy for the design of highly porous and structurally stable networks makes use of metal-org. building blocks that can be assembled on a triply periodic P-minimal geometric surface to produce structures that are interpenetrating-more accurately considered as interwoven.  The authors used 4,4',4''-benzene-1,3,5-triyltribenzoic acid (H3BTB), Cu(NO3)2e, and DMF to prep. Cu3(BTB)2(H2O)3·(DMF)9(H2O)2 (MOF-14), whose structure reveals a pair of interwoven metal-org. frameworks that are mutually reinforced.  The structure contains remarkably large pores, 16.4 Å in diam., in which voluminous amts. of gases and org. solvents can be reversibly sorbed.
(b) Farrell, R. P.; Hambley, T. W.; Lay, P. A.
A New Class of Layered Microporous Materials: Crystal Structure of Disodium Pentakis(trimethylphenylammonium) Bis[tris(oxalato(2-))chromate(III)] Chloride Pentahydrate
Farrell, Rodney P.; Hambley, Trevor W.; Lay, Peter A.

The synthesis and crystal structure of Na2(NMe3Ph)5[Cr(ox)3]2Cl·5H2O are described.  This is the first member of a new class of microporous layered materials.  It has an unusual structure in which the org. cation acts both as a template to produce pores and as a spacer to give a pillared layer structure.  While the template occupies some of the holes of the large rings produced by three Na+ and three [Cr(ox)3]3- ions, some of the holes are vacant.  All of the pores within a layer have the same chirality, but the chirality alternates between the layers, making the material achiral.
(a) Abrahams, B. F.; Hoskins, B. F.; Michael, D. M.; Robson, R.
Assembly of porphyrin building blocks into network structures with large channels
Abrahams, B. F.; Hoskins, B. F.; Michall, D. M.; Robson, R.

The crystal structures of solvated Cu(tpp)CuBF4 (I) and Cu(tcp)BF4 (II) where H2tpp = 5,10,15,20-tetra(4-pyridyl)-21H,23H-porphine and H2tcp = 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-cyanoophenyl)-21H,23H-porphine were detd.  I is tetragonal, space group P‾42c, with a 14.202(6) and c 26.644(9) Å; R = 0.112 for 529 reflections.  II is orthorhombic, space group Cccm, with a 23.69(1), b 27.26(2), and c 32.76(1) Å; R = 0.142 for 457 reflections.  Porphyrin building blocks can be used to construct 3-dimensional networks with the topol. of the PtS structure (equal nos. of square-planar and tetrahedral centers), contg. large channels.  The channels are filled with solvent mols., and cryst. order is lost on solvent removal.  Nevertheless, the results show that it is possible to use simple mol. building blocks to engineer specific frameworks which, if they can be made robust, may offer new catalytic potential.
An acentric, three-dimensional coordination polymer: synthesis and structure of [Cu(pyrimidine)2]BF4
Angewandte Chemie, International Edition in English

[Cu(pyrimidine)2]BF4 (I) crystals were prepd. by diffusing THF into NO2Ph-MeCN soln. of [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 and pyrimidine.  I.n(solvent) is orthorhombic, space group Cmc21, a 20.417(1), b 16.598(1), c 15.912(1)Å, R = 0.0849.  The Cu is tetrahedrally coordinated by 4 N atoms from 4 different pyrimidine ligands.  Each pyrimidine bridges 2 Cu(I) atoms leading to a 3-dimensional framework.  Each BF4- is anchored to the framework through short f...H-Cring hydrogen bonds.  The coordination polymer is a corner-shared network consisting of 8-rings of tetrahedra connected together with 4-rings to form elliptical channels, similar to feldspar.
(c) Chen, B.; Eddaoudi, M.; Reineke, T. M.; Kampf, J. W.; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M.
Cu2(ATC)·6H2O: Design of Open Metal Sites in Porous Metal-Organic Crystals (ATC: 1,3,5,7-Adamantane Tetracarboxylate)
Chen, Banglin; Eddaoudi, M.; Reineke, T. M.; Kampf, J. W.; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

[Cu2(ATC)(H2O)2]·4H2O (ATC = 1,3,5,7-adamantanetetracarboxylate) was prepd. and its crystal structure detd.  The structure consists of a porous metal-org. framework (MOF) with a 3-D channel system filled with the water guest mols.  Thermal treatment removes all of the water mols., including those coordinated to copper, to give Cu2(ATC) which has a rigid and porous 3-D structure which was also detd. by x-ray crystallog.  Magnetic susceptibility data indicate an increase in the antiferromagnetic coupling in the dehydrated complex which is expected as a result of the shorter Cu-O bond distances.  Gas sorption isotherms for sorption of N2 and Ar by Cu2(ATC) show fully reversible behavior.  Sorption of CH2Cl2 is immeasurably fast and sorption of C6H6, CCl4 and C6H12 showed first order rate consts. (k × 104 s-1) 11.1, 5.3, 1.4, resp.

Synthesis and structure of [Me4N][CuPt(CN)4]: an infinite three-dimensional framework related to PtS which generates intersecting hexagonal channels of large cross section
Gable, Robert W.; Hoskins, Bernard F.; Robson, Richard
Journal of the Chemical Society, Chemical Communications

[Me4N][CuPt(CN)4] was prepd. and its crystal structure detd. as tetragonal, space group P42/mmc, with a 7.613(2), c 13.501(2) Å, Z = 2, R = 0.078, Rw = 0.102.  It consists of an infinite 3-dimensional [CuIPtII(CN)4]nn- framework related to the PtS structure, which generates 2 mutually perpendicular and equiv. sets of hexagonal channels of large cross-section (largest Pt-Pt diagonal, 13.50 Å) together with large empty square channels perpendicular to the hexagonal channels.

Geometric requirements and examples of important structures in the assembly of square building blocks
Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Vodak, David; Sudik, Andrea; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

The basic structures for linking squares into polyhedra and networks (reticulation) are enumerated, and corresponding examples are described in which crystals were synthesized by linking paddle wheel (square) units into metal-org. frameworks (MOFs)-named MOF-102 to MOF-112. The secondary building unit (SBU) was identified as a useful tool in the anal. of complex metal-org. frameworks (MOFs).  The authors illustrate its applicability to rationalizing MOF crystal structures by anal. of nine new MOFs which were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction.  Tetrahedral SBUs in Zn(ADC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-31; H2ADC = acetylenedicarboxylic acid; HTEA = monoprotonated triethylamine), Cd(ATC)·[Cd(H2O)6](H2O)5 (MOF-32; H4ATC = adamantanetetracarboxylic acid), and Zn2(ATB)(H2O)·(H2O)3(DMF)3 (MOF-33; H4ATB = adamantanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into diamond networks, while those of Ni2(ATC)(H2O)4·(H2O)4 (MOF-34) have the structure of the Al network in SrAl2.  Frameworks constructed from less sym. tetrahedral SBUs have the Ga network of CaGa2O4 as illustrated by Zn2(ATC)·(EtOH)2(H2O)2 (MOF-35) structure.  Squares and tetrahedral SBUs in Zn2(MTB)(H2O)2·(DMF)6(H2O)5 (MOF-36; H4MTB = methanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into the PtS network, which is the simplest structure type known for the assembly of these shapes.  The octahedral SBUs found in Zn2(NDC)3·[(HTEA)(DEF)(ClBz)]2 (MOF-37; H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid) form the most common structure for linking octahedral shapes, namely, the B network in CaB6.  New structure types for linking triangular and trigonal prismatic SBUs are found in Zn3O(BTC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-38; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Zn3O(HBTB)2(H2O)·(DMF)0.5(H2O)3 (MOF-39; H3BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoic acid). Two families of mol. frameworks which grow as homochiral single crystals are described.  Both consist of multiple interpenetration of the three-connected chiral (10,3)-a (Y*) network and result from the tridentate coordination of the 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (btc) ligand to octahedral metal centers which act as linear connectors.  The nature of the interpenetration is controlled by the auxiliary ligands bound in the equatorial plane of the metal center.  Ethylene glycol (eg) binds in a unidentate fashion to form phase A which has 28% accessible solvent vol. and contains four interpenetrating (10,3)-a networks.  1,2-Propanediol (1,2-pd) coordinates as a bidentate ligand to yield a phase B with a greatly enhanced 51% of solvent accessible vol., because only two (distorted) (10,3)-a' networks interpenetrate.  Ligands in the void space and bound to the metal center can both be liberated thermally: the kinetics of this process gave microporous desolvated cryst. A and B.  The porous phases lose crystallinity reversibly upon further loss of ligands bound to the equatorial metal: crystallinity is restored upon exposure to the vapors of simple alcs., which can also effect conversion of B to A.  Both phases present interpenetrating network topologies that are unique to chem. and adopt space groups that are new for mol. solids: A crystallizes in P4232 and B adopts I4132.  B can be grown homochirally from enantiomerically pure diol template.  The stereochem. of the alc. bound to the metal controls the helicity of the chiral framework.  The structure detn. of the 1,2-propanediol phase represents the 1st demonstration that chiral mols. can specifically template helix handedness in a chiral porous framework solid.

The isomorphous structures of M(tcm)2 [MII = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Cd or Hg; tcm- = tricyanomethanide, C(CN)3-] contain two interpenetrating rutile-related networks generated by octahedral six-connecting metal ions and trigonal three-connecting tcm- anions.  The detailed variable temp. and variable field magnetic properties of this series of high-spin complexes generally point to the existence of very weak intraframework coupling with no evidence for long range magnetic order or interframework effects.  Cr(tcm)2 is the most strongly coupled and displays a field independent max. in susceptibility at 14.5 K and a J value of -1.6 cm-1 (using a -2JS1·S2 Heisenberg chain model); Co(tcm)2 displays high temp. magnetic moments typical of essentially uncoupled octahedral centers but with a most unusual field dependence in μCo obsd. at <10 K, probably due to very weak ferromagnetic coupling, and an Msat value in high fields, at 2 K, which is significantly less than that expected for S = 3/2.  Doping of M(tcm)2 with another M' member of the series leads to a crystal structure isomorphous with M(tcm)2 in which the dopant metal M' occupies the M site in a random fashion.  The resultant magnetism is simply intermediate between those of the parent phases.  The isomorphous structures of [M(tcm)2(EtOH)2] (MII = Co or Ni) contain pseudo square-grid sheets in which the tcm- ligands are each coordinated to two metal ions and act as a kinked bridge.  Each metal is coordinated to four tcm- anions in an equatorial arrangement and to two axial EtOH ligands.  Extensive intrasheet H bonding exists between the EtOH mols. and the uncoordinated nitrile of the tcm- bridges.

[o-HO2CC6H4NHC(O)]2 (obbzH4), MnCu(obbz).5H2O (I), MnCu(obbz).1H2O (II), and NiCu(obbz).6H2O (III) were prepd. and characterized.  The crystal structure of III was detd.  It crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/n, with a 7.764(1), b 12.559 (3), c 20.083(3) Å, β 97.56°, and Z = 4.  The structure consists of isolated heterodinuclear units with octahedral Ni(II) and square planar Cu(II) ions bridged by an oxamido group.  III is not isomorphous to I or to II, neither of which was obtained in the form of single crystals suitable for x-ray work.  To get information on their structure, their XANES and EXAFS spectra at both Mn and Cu edges were studied, as well as their powder x-ray patterns.  I and II have very similar structures, with 4 noncoordinated H2O mols. in the former compd.  Cu(II) is in elongated tetragonal surroundings and Mn(II) in octahedral surroundings.  The radius of the 1st shell around Mn is 2.17(2) for (I) and 2.16(2) Å for II.  Mn is surrounded by 6 O atoms; 2 of these atoms belong to an oxamido group, 1 to a carboxylato group, and 1 to a H2O mol. in the equatorial plane; the O atoms in the apical positions belong to other carboxylato groups, forming a 2- or 3-dimensional network.  The magnetic properties of III were studied at 4.2-300 K.  They are typical of an isolated heteropair with a doublet-quartet energy gap 3J/2 equal to -156(3) cm-1.  The magnetic properties of I down to 4 K, are characteristic of alternating bimetallic chains with a min. in the λMT vs. T plot, χM being the molar magnetic susceptibility per MnCu unit.  At 2.3 K, χMT for I shows a sharp max. dcue to a 3-dimensional antiferromagnetic ordering.  In contrast, the χMT vs. T plot for II diverges at T < Tc = 14 K.  Below Tc, II exhibits a spontaneous magnetization.  The field dependences of the magnetization M for I and II were compared.  For both compds., the satn. magnetization corresponds to a S = 2 resulting spin per MnCu unit.  Moreover, II at 4.2 K exhibits a M = f(H) hysteresis loop characteristic of a soft magnet.  The powder x-band ESR spectra of I and II were recorded at various temps. ≥15 K.  The comparison of the line widths suggests that the mechanism of the magnetic ordering obsd. for II is of exchange interaction nature rather than of dipolar nature. Although zeolites and related materials combine nanoporosity with high thermal stability, they are difficult to modify or derivatize in a systematic way.  A highly porous metal coordination polymer [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n (TMA is benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate) was formed in 80% yield.  It has interconnected [Cu2(O2CR)4] units (R is an arom. ring), which create a three-dimensional system of channels with a pore size of 1 nm and an accessible porosity of ∼40% in the solid.  Unlike zeolites, the channel linings can be chem. functionalized; for example, the aqua ligands can be replaced by pyridines.  TGA and high-temp. single-crystal diffractometry indicate that the framework is stable up to 240°.

I crystallizes as monoclinic, space group P21/n, a 10.351(4), b 19.130(4), c 11.225(2) Å, β 97.82(2)°, Z = 4, R = 0.043, Rw = 0.040.  The structure consists of binuclear units with Mn(II) and Cu(II) bridged by a carboxylate group (Mn...Cu = 5.195(1) Å). II crystallizes as monoclinic, space group P21/c, a 9.294(2), b 17.981(4), c 15.021(2) Å, β 100.00(2)°, Z = 4, R = 0.0345, and Rw = 0.0390. The chains are connected through Cu...Br contacts of 2.971 Å.  The configuration around the carboxylate bridge is again of the anti-syn type.  The magnetic properties of both compds. were investigated at 2-300 K.  For I, the molar magnetic susceptibility χM follows the Curie law expected for uncoupled Mn(II) and Cu(II) ions.  For II, χM varies as expected for a Mn(II)-Cu(II) pair with a quintet-septet energy gap 3J = -87.0 cm-1.  This rather strong antiferromagnetic interaction occurs through the oxamide bridge.  For both compds., the interaction through the carboxylate bridge is negligible owing to the anti-syn configuration around this bridge.  The EPR spectra reveal long-range interactions not detectable through magnetic susceptibility measurements.  The structural and magnetic differences between the 2 compds. are discussed.

Single crystals of MnCu(obbz)(H2O)3.DMF (1; H4obbz = N,N'-oxamidobis(benzoic acid) were obtained.  1 Is a precursor of the mol.-based magnet MnCu(obbz).H2O (2) exhibiting a spontaneous magnetization at Tc <14 K.  1 Crystallizes as orthorhombic, space group Pbca, a 10.3006(6), b 22.375(2), c 19.639(1) Å, Z = 8 (MnCu units), R = 0.041, Rw = 0.037. The conformation around the carboxylato bridge is of the syn-anti type.  The chains stack on top of 1 another along the a axis, and are sepd. by noncoordinated DMF mols. along the b axis.  The magnetic susceptibility of 1, studied at ≥2 K, is characteristic of 1-dimensional ferrimagnetic behavior with a min. in the χMT vs. T curve at -35 K (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility and T is the temp.).  Two theor. models were used to interpret these data.  Model 1 consists of treating SMn = 5/2 as a classical spin and SCu = 1/2 as a quantum spin, with 2 interaction parameters J1 and J2.  This model might be of limited applicability for 1, due to the low value of the ratio J1/J2.  Model 2 describes the system as consisting of chains of oxamido-bridged MnIICuII units weakly coupled in a ferromagnetic fashion through carboxylato bridges.  Knowing the crystal structure of 1, it was possible to propose a scheme describing the irreversible transformation from 1 to the mol.-based magnet 2.  In 2 each Mn(II) ion belonging to a chain would bind to 2 free carboxylato O atoms belonging to the adjacent chains just above and below along the a axis, affording a 2-dimensional network.  The interplane interactions would be favored by the removal of the DMF mols.

Metal nuclearity modulated four-, six-, and eight-connected entangled frameworks based on mono-, bi-, and trimetallic cores as nodes
Wang, Xin-Long; Qin, Chao; Wang, En-Bo; Su, Zhong-Min

To study the relation between network connectivity and metal nuclearity, the authors designed and synthesized three-dimensional (3D) entangled coordination frameworks based on different metal cores, [Zn2(bdc)2(L)2]·2H2O (1), [Zn(bdc)(L)0.5] (2), [Zn(oba)(L)0.5] (3) and [Cd3(bdc)3(L)2(H2O)2] (4) by self-assembly of d10 metal salts with the flexible long-chain ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (L), and with the rigid and nonrigid arom. dicarboxylate ligands 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) and 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate) (oba).  Compd. 1 exhibits a 3-fold interpenetrated diamondoid array typically based on a tetrahedral 2nd building unit (SBU) at a single Zn center.  Compd. 2 adopts a 3-fold interpenetrated α-Po-type network that is built from bimetallic cores as six-connected vertexes.  The structure of 3 also consists of dinuclear units comprising a novel (3,4)-connected 3-fold interpenetrated net with complex (4.6 × 10)-(4.62 × 103) topol. when single Zn centers act as four-connected nodes (or the α-Po topol. if dinuclear units are considered as six-connected nodes).  4, Derived from a cross-linked 5-fold interpenetrated diamond-like substructure, is an unusual example of a self-penetrating coordination framework displaying an unprecedented eight-connected 42068 topol. with trinuclear Cd clusters as eight-connected nodes which, to the authors' knowledge, not only defines a new topol. for eight-connected coordination networks, but also represents the highest connected topol. presently known for self-penetrating systems.  Detailed structural comparison of these complexes indicates that the increase in metal nuclearity induces the progressive increase in the connectivities of the ultimate nets: i.e., the metal nuclearity plays a significant role in tuning the connectivity of a specific network.  The thermal and luminescent properties of these compds. are discussed.
